nodes.text: Machine learning classifiers (KNN, Random Forest, SVM) can assist early detection of lung cancer from CT images, improving diagnostic accuracy and patient outcomes
Dataset: LIDC-IDRI CT image dataset used for training and testing; additional samples obtained from AHRC and AIMS for validation
Image preprocessing methods applied: resizing, normalization, CLAHE, Wiener, adaptive Gaussian, Gaussian and Gabor filtering to reduce noise and standardize images
Classifiers implemented and compared: K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) with Euclidean distance, Support Vector Machine (SVM) with hyperplane separation, and Random Forest ensemble of decision trees
Training and evaluation protocol: dataset sample of 500 images, images downsampled, 70% training 30% test split, and 5-fold cross-validation used for performance estimation
Result: SVM classifier achieved average accuracy 95.06% across 5-fold cross-validation (per-fold accuracies reported), with high precision, recall and F1
Result: KNN classifier achieved average accuracy 86.89% across 5-fold cross-validation with reported per-fold metrics
Result: Random Forest classifier achieved average accuracy 81.96% across 5-fold cross-validation with reported per-fold metrics
Evidence: Confusion matrices presented and reported ROC-AUC values exceeding 0.99 for each class, indicating strong class discrimination
Claim: SVM outperforms KNN and Random Forest on this dataset due to better handling of complex, high-dimensional decision boundaries
Conclusion: The proposed SVM-based diagnostic approach shows promise for earlier and more accurate lung cancer detection and could contribute to improved clinical outcomes if validated further
Evidence: Validation performed on small local sample sets from AHRC and AIMS under supervision of a radiologist to corroborate model outputs
Method detail: Image segmentation techniques included thresholding and marker-controlled watershed; image enhancement included contrast and color-space modifications
Claim: Model evaluation used standard performance metrics including accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, sensitivity, specificity, FAR and FRR
Limitation: Small experimental sample size (500 images) and limited external validation restrict generalizability of reported performance
Future work: Expand and diversify dataset across populations and stages, and further improve model performance and reliability with larger multicenter data
